channel.title: Linux
channel.description:
My friend gave me his linux, but he gave me the IP to a website, and he gave me the details
https://108.167.163.112:4643/vz/cp
How do I connect to the Linux?

item.title: Linux
item.dc:creator: @Daginith Daginith
item.description:
@Daginith wrote:

[quote=“latifundio, post:28, topic:435992”]slitaz to me is the best distro ever

[code]About SliTaz

SliTaz is an open source and free operating system providing a fully featured
desktop or server in less than 35 MB. SliTaz is simple to use, fast and stable.
We have an active community and contributors from all over the world
making SliTaz finer every day. [/code]

[/quote]
woah, looks nice, im going to install it to a usb, and have it as a ‘Portable OS’, since the whole OS is a maximum of 100mb with everything i need on it. ;D

Read full topic

item.title: Linux
item.dc:creator: @Nothing1 -Nothing
item.description:
@Nothing1 wrote:

[quote=“Daginith, post:23, topic:435992”][quote author=ziplock link=topic=538715.msg3942724#msg3942724 date=1331553015]

Linux is great

ArchLinux is the best.
PCLinuxOS is a close second
then Fedora

And please tell me what’s the difference? They all look the same to me.

Is this trolling? If not:

ArchLinux is a light weight build, aimed at pro users (nothing un-needed comes with it, and you have to do a command-line install)

PCLinuxOS is aimed at all levels, and is basically an “open linux”, i’d call it because you are able to edit things more easily, and gain root access any time. (Personally, i think this the best one for programming)

Fedora is in between intermediate, and advanced, and is more of a ‘Business’ one I’d call it, and its great for hosting anything.

Wait…wait…How can you program if all you see is a command prompt?

Command line text editors such as Vim.
[/quote]
You can also install virtual desktops such as gnome or KDE.[/quote]
…I was trolling.

Read full topic

And please tell me what’s the difference? They all look the same to me.

ArchLinux is a light weight build, aimed at pro users (nothing un-needed comes with it, and you have to do a command-line install)

PCLinuxOS is aimed at all levels, and is basically an “open linux”, i’d call it because you are able to edit things more easily, and gain root access any time. (Personally, i think this the best one for programming)

Fedora is in between intermediate, and advanced, and is more of a ‘Business’ one I’d call it, and its great for hosting anything.

Wait…wait…How can you program if all you see is a command prompt?
[/quote]

Command line text editors such as Vim.[/quote]
You can also install virtual desktops such as gnome or KDE.

Read full topic

item.title: Linux
item.dc:creator: @Aff Aff
item.description:
@Aff wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:19, topic:435992”][quote author=Daginith link=topic=538715.msg3942239#msg3942239 date=1331503895]

as a long time linux user, i can assure you that all mainstream distros are more or less the same.

with what i talked about, only Fedora is mainstream

debian, ubuntu, suse, mint, centos, gentoo…???

ewwww ubuntu. i hate it. Its like a windows vista clone.
[/quote]

how could you even compare the two ._.[/quote]

i use windows 7 and it is the exactly same as a mac and a unubtuntu and a red hat
